section_title: A6 Applying Probability-Based Phase Selection for UNSAT Case
section_purpose: This section describes a practical application of the proposed probability-based phase selection heuristic: using the solver's early behavior under this heuristic as a lightweight classifier to predict if an instance is likely UNSAT, and then adaptively switching to a UNSAT-tuned configuration.
key_points: The phase selection method, which prioritizes assignments likely to satisfy the circuit, can also act as a lightweight classifier for unsatisfiability prediction.

If the solver fails to find a solution within a predefined time budget using this heuristic, the instance is considered likely UNSAT, triggering a dynamic switch to a UNSAT-tuned solver configuration.

The strategy is implemented on top of CaDiCaL with a 5-second time budget for the initial SAT-oriented phase, significantly reducing average solving time on UNSAT instances from 166.26 seconds to 80.36 seconds on the LECUNSAT dataset.

algorithms: Timeout-based switching mechanism: Uses early-stage solver behavior under SAT-oriented phase heuristic as a signal to predict unsatisfiability and adaptively switch configurations.

reproducibility_notes: Implementation details: Strategy is built on top of the CaDiCaL solver.
Key parameter: The initial time budget for the SAT-oriented phase heuristic is set to 5 seconds before considering a switch.
Dataset used for evaluation: LECUNSAT dataset.
Performance metric: Solving time and number of solved instances within a 300-second timeout.
